original_text: Fig. 9 displays the growth of two of the main corrosion products that develop or form on the surface of Cu40Zn with time, hydrozincite (Fig. 9a) and Cu2O (Fig. 9b). It should be remembered that both phases were present already from start of the exposure. The data is presented in absorbance units and allows comparisons to be made of the amounts of each species between the two Cu40Zn surfaces investigated, DP and HZ7. The tendency is very clear that the formation rates of both hydrozincite and cuprite are quite suppressed for Cu40Zn with preformed hydrozincite (HZ7) compared to the diamond polished surface (DP). In summary, without being able to consider the formation of simonkolleite, it can be concluded that an increased surface coverage of hydrozincite reduces the initial spreading ability of the NaCl-containing droplets and thereby lowers the overall formation rate of hydrozincite and cuprite.
original_translation: Fig. La figura 9 muestra el crecimiento de dos de los principales productos de corrosión que se desarrollan o forman en la superficie de Cu40Zn con el tiempo, hidrozincita (Fig. 9a) y Cu2O (Fig. 9b). Debe recordarse que ambas fases estaban presentes desde el inicio de la exposición. Los datos se presentan en unidades de absorbancia y permiten realizar comparaciones de las cantidades de cada especie entre las dos superficies de Cu40Zn investigadas, DP y HZ7. La tendencia es muy clara de que las tasas de formación tanto de hidrozincita como de cuprita están bastante suprimidas para Cu40Zn con hidrozincita preformada (HZ7) en comparación con la superficie pulida con diamante (DP). En resumen, sin poder considerar la formación de simonkolleita, se puede concluir que una mayor cobertura superficial de hidrozincita reduce la capacidad de dispersión inicial de las gotas que contienen NaCl y, por lo tanto, disminuye la tasa de formación general de hidrozincita y cuprita.
original_sentences: 9 displays the growth of two of the main corrosion products that develop or form on the surface of Cu40Zn with time, hydrozincite (Fig. 9a) and Cu2O (Fig. 9b).
It should be remembered that both phases were present already from start of the exposure.
The data is presented in absorbance units and allows comparisons to be made of the amounts of each species between the two Cu40Zn surfaces investigated, DP and HZ7.
The tendency is very clear that the formation rates of both hydrozincite and cuprite are quite suppressed for Cu40Zn with preformed hydrozincite (HZ7) compared to the diamond polished surface (DP).

In summary, without being able to consider the formation of simonkolleite, it can be concluded that an increased surface coverage of hydrozincite reduces the initial spreading ability of the NaCl-containing droplets and thereby lowers the overall formation rate of hydrozincite and cuprite.
